At around 4:50 of Tutorial6, the energy levels of a harmonic oscillator are mentioned. I was under the impression the En=(n+0.5). But somehow, they show En=n. Am I missing something?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi Ganesh, thanks for your question. You raise a valid point, but i think we mentioned it in lecture and tutorial 6. We can add or substract a constant from the energies, and the physics will not change: all the statistical weights pi_i gain a factor exp(-beta/2), but this factor will be absorbed in the normalization. So choosing energies 0,1,2,3,4 instead of 1/2, 3/2, 5/2, 7/2 is just a matter of convenience. What really counts are the differences in energy. What I am explaining here is valid only in non-relativistic physics, though. Best, Werner

Hi, I'm watching lecture 6 and am confused about the relevance of the harmonic potential to the path of a wave function. A particle moves from point x to x'. As Statistical Mechanics, we can simulate paths that it can take to reach x'. But what is the relevance of the harmonic potential to the path? Like the Monte-Carlo pebble throwing, is a step towards x' to be rejected if it lands beyond the curve of the harmonic potential?
Upvotes:
1
I assume because there's exact analytic results for wave function for a particle trapped in a harmonic potential V(x) = 1/2 x^2, it is a good case to study and compare with numerical simulation, so you know if something is grossly wrong. But there may be other deeper meanings to picking harmonic potential...
Upvotes:
0
@Anon my interpretation of Noel Evans 's question is different (see post below ). However, I would like to append to your post, which I believe is a reply to the question: Why consider the Harmonic potential in the first place? You wrote: there may be other deeper meanings to picking harmonic potential... I think there is: A generic potential can be written as a power series. Let it be the Taylor expansion around a point of local minimum. This expansion for a generic potential will contain a second order ($$x^2$$) term. Therefore, you can (almost) always look close enough to the minimum of this potential well and the potential will look harmonic to you. This is correct up to order $$\mathcal{O}(\delta x^3)$$, where $$\delta x$$ is the distance from the point of minimum. bottom line The harmonic potential is an approximation for a generic potential in the vicinity of a minimum.
Upvotes:

@ Noel Evans Judging by Anon's post , we have interpreted your question differently. I will attempt to answer: How does the Harmonic potential affect the MC path integration? Referring to naive_harmonic_path.py (week #5) calculation for the Metropolis rejection algorithm: old_weight = (rho_free(x[knext], x[k], dtau) * rho_free(x[k], x[kprev], dtau) * math.exp(-0.5 * dtau * x[k] ** 2)) new_weight = (rho_free(x[knext], x_new, dtau) * rho_free(x_new, x[kprev], dtau) * math.exp(-0.5 * dtau * x_new ** 2)) Note that the last element of each weight (old/new) comes from the (harmonic) potential. So it is not a straight-forward geometric (or 'graphic') issue as implied from your post. It affects the assigned weights. Trying to provide some intuition : Recall that the path can be thought as a trajectory along the x-axis with the beta axis taking the role of time (upper in the curve is later in time). Now imagine the random walker as drunk person (which is why he is walking randomly) connected by a spring to the pole of a street light. This would create a bias in his path towards the street light (minimum of the potential).

Hi there, In quantum physics, each particle occupies a given quantum state. For example, an electron orbiting around a Hydrogen atom will occupy states characterized by the quantum numbers n, l, m, s. To this state is associated a wavefunction $$\phi$$ whose square $$\overline{\phi} \phi$$ gives the density of probability for a particle to be at given position x. Now the question of indistinguishability comes from the fact that you cannot differentiate one electron from another and that there is no sense is saying that number 1 has quantum numbers n', l', m', s' and number 2 has quantum numbers n', l', m', s' since you cannot number them. This has serious physical implications since you want the wavefunction of the whole system (with the different particles) to be invariant under permutations. Note that since the phase of the global wavefunction $$\mathrm{arg}{\phi}$$ has no physical significance (it will be wiped out when you take the module), this invariance requirement is only 'up to a common phase', that is, after a permutation you could have multiplied everything by a common phase $$e^{i \theta}$$. This requirement shows that there is in fact not one type of particles, as you said, but two: Bosons, whose wavefunction remain identical when you exhange two particles, and Fermions, whose wavefunction is multiplied by a phase $$-1$$ when you exchange two particles. Bosons and fermions behave very differently since two Bosons can occupy the same quantum state, whereas two fermions cannot occupy the same quantum state (exhanging them would not multiply the wavefunction by $$-1$$). The groundstate (lowest energy) configuration of N fermions will be to occupy the lowest N levels of energy: it is the 'Fermi sea'. The groundstate of N bosons will be simply to put all the N bosons in the lowest energy state since there is no Pauli exclusion principle in this case.

Hi there, In quantum physics, each particle occupies a given quantum state. For example, an electron orbiting around a Hydrogen atom will occupy states characterized by the quantum numbers n, l, m, s. To this state is associated a wavefunction $$\phi$$ whose square $$\overline{\phi} \phi$$ gives the density of probability for a particle to be at given position x. Now the question of indistinguishability comes from the fact that you cannot differentiate one electron from another and that there is no sense is saying that number 1 has quantum numbers n', l', m', s' and number 2 has quantum numbers n', l', m', s' since you cannot number them. This has serious physical implications since you want the wavefunction of the whole system (with the different particles) to be invariant under permutations. Note that since the phase of the global wavefunction $$\mathrm{arg}{\phi}$$ has no physical significance (it will be wiped out when you take the module), this invariance requirement is only 'up to a common phase', that is, after a permutation you could have multiplied everything by a common phase $$e^{i \theta}$$. This requirement shows that there is in fact not one type of particles, as you said, but two: Bosons, whose wavefunction remain identical when you exhange two particles, and Fermions, whose wavefunction is multiplied by a phase $$-1$$ when you exchange two particles. Bosons and fermions behave very differently since two Bosons can occupy the same quantum state, whereas two fermions cannot occupy the same quantum state (exhanging them would not multiply the wavefunction by $$-1$$). The groundstate (lowest energy) configuration of N fermions will be to occupy the lowest N levels of energy: it is the 'Fermi sea'. The groundstate of N bosons will be simply to put all the N bosons in the lowest energy state since there is no Pauli exclusion principle in this case.
